treatment.etymology: [Greek splen, spleen; thought by Dioscorides to be useful for treating spleen diseases]
treatment.description: Roots fibrous, not proliferous or proliferous and producing tiny plantlets. Stems erect, rarely long-creeping; scales basally attached, clathrate. Petioles not articulate. Blades 1--4-pinnate, of diverse size and shape. Indusia present. x = 36.
treatment.number_of_infrataxa: Species ca. 700 (28 species, 3 nothospecies in the flora):
treatment.author: Warren H. Wagner Jr.
Robbin C. Moran
Charles R. Werth

key_statement.statement: Blades simple, pinnatifid, or forked (sometimes with free pinnae at base), not pinnate throughout.
Blades pinnate throughout or pinnatifid only in distal 1/3, pinnae undivided to 1–3-divided.
Blades less than 2–3 mm wide, linear, frequently forking or with 1–3 small, narrow projections.
Blades more than 10 mm wide, linear-lanceolate to lanceolate, if lobed, segments resembling adnate pinnae.
Veins anastomosing to form areoles; blades rooting at tip.
Veins free; blades with apical buds or not but not rooting at tip.
Blades simple, linear to oblanceolate.
Blades pinnatifid, elliptic, lanceolate, to deltate.
Blades cordate at base; roots not proliferous.
Blades tapered at base; roots proliferous.
Petioles 1 cm or less, dull; stem scales 0.6–1 mm wide, sparsely denticulate.
Petioles 1–10 cm, lustrous; stem scales less than 0.5 mm wide, entire.
Petioles dark-pigmented only at base; blade narrowly deltate.
Petioles and proximal midrib darkly pigmented abaxially; blade oblong- lanceolate.
Blades 2–4-pinnate, with only largest pinnae divided to all pinnae divided.
Blades 1-pinnate, pinnae undivided (except in some individuals of A. pumilum).
Blades deltate-ovate, with 2–5 pairs of pinnae; pinnae generally deltate-ovate to obdeltate, rarely lanceolate to narrowly elliptic; color in living plants dull bluish green.
Blades ovate-lanceolate to linear, with 5–20 pairs of pinnae; pinnae linear to oblong; color in living plants shiny green.
Delicate root proliferations usually present (commonly buried in mossy soil in crevices, but enabling clone formation); damp, shaded limestone; Florida.
Delicate root proliferations absent or rare; mainly rock crevices; plants not in Florida.
Spores uniform and normal.
Spores of different sizes and shapes, malformed (irregular in size and shape).
Blades oblong-lanceolate, mostly 2- pinnate; pinnae lanceolate to oblong- lanceolate.
Blades narrowly lanceolate, 2–3- pinnate; pinnae ovate to ovate- deltate.
Blades linear-lanceolate, s Florida.
Blades oblong-lanceolate, c Florida.
Medial pinnae pinnate throughout; pinnules mostly deeply notched apically.
Medial pinnae pinnate only in proximal 1/2; pinnules mostly shallowly notched apically.
Buds at blade, pinna, and pinnule apices minute, scaly, dormant; Arizona.
Buds absent; foothills and mountains in e United States and s Rocky Mountains.
Petioles all pale green except at base.
Petioles dark reddish brown.
Blades lanceolate to linear- lanceolate, 1–2-pinnate; proximal pinnae often somewhat reduced; e United States foothills and mountains.
Blades deltate-ovate to deltate- lanceolate, 2–3-pinnate; proximal pinnae usually largest; s Rocky Mountains.
Pinna pairs 1–2(–4); blades ovate-deltate, with fine nonglandular hairs on veins.
Pinna pairs 5–35; blades mainly oblong to lanceolate, usually with glandular hairs or narrow hairlike scales on veins or blades glabrous.
Pinnae with conspicuous basal auricles overlapping rachis; sori inframedial; leaves ± dimorphic, upright and tall, or spreading and short; plants often terrestrial.
Pinnae bases not overlapping rachis; sori medial to supramedial; leaves monomorphic; plants mainly on rock (epiphytic in A. auritum).
Blades mostly 4–9 cm wide, linear- lanceolate to oblong-lanceolate.
Blades mostly less than 3 cm wide, mainly linear.
Blades linear-lanceolate, to 35 cm; pinna pairs 10–22, base with conspicuous acroscopic auricle; epiphytic on tree trunks.
Blades oblong to oblong-lanceolate, to 20 cm; pinna pairs 4–8, base with or without small acroscopic auricle; on mossy limestone.
Sori 1(–3), mainly confined to basiscopic side of strongly asymmetric pinnae.
Sori 4–10, on both sides of costa of nearly symmetric pinnae.
Blade apex prolonged into whiplike extension of rachis terminating in bud.
Blade apex not prolonged, terminal bud absent.
Pinnae ovate, oblong-ovate, to rhombic, mainly 4–7 mm, length 1–2 times width.
Pinnae oblong-lanceolate to oblong, mainly 6–10 mm, length 3–5 times width.
Rachises dark reddish brown throughout.
Rachises dark in proximal 1/3–2/3 or only at base.
Rachises dark in proximal 1/3–2/3; pinna margins entire to shallowly crenate.
Rachises dark only at base; pinna margins dentate-crenate.
Pinnae with basiscopic 1/2 much reduced; blades mainly less than 1 cm wide; n North America.
Pinnae nearly symmetric; blades mainly more than 1 cm wide; s Florida.
Pinna margins deeply lobed, especially acroscopic and distal margins, cut 1/3 or more distance from margin to costa; s California.
Pinna margins nearly entire or shallowly crenate- dentate; se United States to e Arizona.
Pinna margins nearly entire; sori supramedial; spores 32; widespread in s United States.
Pinna margins ± shallowly crenate- dentate; sori medial to inframedial; spores 32 or 64; local in se United States.
Pinna margins shallowly crenulate; auricle present at pinna base; veins obscure; spores 32 per sporangium.
Pinna margins serrate to crenate; auricle rudimentary or absent at pinna base; veins evident; spores 64 per sporangium. ..
